1.one: AWAKE! For Morning in the Bowl of Night
1.two: Has flung the Stone that puts the Stars to Flight:
1.three: And lo! the Hunter of the East has caught
1.four: The Sultan's Turret in a Noose of Light.

2.one: Dreaming when Dawn's Left Hand was in the Sky
2.two: I heard a Voice within the Tavern cry,
2.three: "Awake, my Little ones, and fill the Cup
2.four: Before Life's Liquor in its Cup be dry."

3.one: And, as the Cock crew, those who stood before
3.two: The Tavern shouted – "Open then the Door!
3.three: You know how little while we have to stay,
3.four: And once departed, may return no more."

4.one: Now the New Year reviving old Desires,
4.two: The thoughtful Soul to Solitude retires,
4.three: Where the WHITE HAND OF MOSES on the bough
4.four: Puts out, and Jesus from the Ground suspires.

5.one: Iram indeed is gone with all its Rose,
5.two: And Jamshyd's Sev'n-ring'd Cup where no-one knows;
5.three: But still the Vine her ancient Ruby yields,
5.four: And still a Garden by the Water blows.

6.one: And David's Lips are lock't; but in divine
6.two: High piping Pehlevi, with "Wine! Wine! Wine!
6.three: Red Wine!" — the Nightingale cries to the Rose
6.four: That yellow Cheek of her's to incarnadine.

7.one: Come, fill the Cup, and in the Fire of Spring
7.two: The Winter Garment of Repentance fling:
7.three: The Bird of Time has but a little way
7.four: To fly — and Lo! the Bird is on the Wing.

8.two: Whether the Cup with sweet or bitter run,
8.three: The Wine of Life keeps oozing drop by drop;
8.four: The Leaves of Life keep dropping One by One.

9.one: And look — a thousand Blossoms with the Day
9.two: Woke — and a thousand scatter'd into Clay:
9.three: And this first Summer Month that brings the Rose
9.four: Shall take Jamshyd and Kaikobad away.

10.one: Well let it take them, what have we to do
10.three: Let Zal and Rustum thunder as they will
10.four: Or Hatim call to supper — heed not you.

11.one: With me along some Strip of Herbage strown
11.two: That just divides the desert from the sown,
11.three: Where name of slave and Sultan scarce is known,
11.four: And pity Mahmud on his golden Throne.

12.one: Here with a Loaf of Bread beneath the Bough,
12.two: A Flask of Wine, a Book of Verse — and Thou
12.three: Beside me singing in the wilderness —

13.one: "How sweet is mortal Sovranty!" – think some:
13.two: Others – "How blest the Paradise to come!"
13.three: Ah, take the Cash and let the Credit go
13.four: Nor heed the rumble of a distant Drum!

14.one: Were it not Folly, Spider-like to spin
14.two: The Thread of present Life away to win
14.three: What? For ourselves who know not if we shall
14.four: Breathe out the very Breath we now breathe in!

15.one: Look to the Rose that blows about us – "Lo,
15.two: Laughing," she says, "into the World I blow:
15.three: At once the silken Tassel of my Purse
15.four: Tear, and its Treasure on the Garden throw."

16.one: The Worldly Hope men set their Hearts upon
16.two: Turns Ashes – or it prospers; and anon,
16.three: Like Snow upon the Desert's dusty Face
16.four: Lighting a little Hour or two – is gone.

17.one: And those who husbanded the Golden Grain,
17.two: And those who flung it to the Winds like Rain,
17.three: Alike to no such aureate Earth are turn'd
17.four: As, buried once, Men want dug up again.

18.two: Whose Doorways are alternate Night and Day,
18.three: How Sultan after Sultan with his Pomp
18.four: Abode his Hour or two, and went his way.

19.one: They say the Lion and the Lizard keep
19.two: The Courts where Jamshyd gloried and drank deep;
19.three: And Bahram, that great Hunter – the Wild Ass
19.four: Stamps o'er his head, but cannot break his Sleep.

20.one: I sometimes think that never blows so red
20.two: The Rose as where some buried Caesar bled;
20.three: That every Hyacinth the Garden wears
20.four: Dropt in its Lap from some once lovely Head.

21.one: And this delightful Herb whose tender Green
21.two: Fledges the River's Lip on which we lean —
21.three: Ah, lean upon it lightly! for who knows
21.four: From what once lovely Lip it springs unseen!

22.one: Ah, my Beloved, fill the cup that clears
22.two: TO-DAY of past Regrets and future Fears —
22.three: Tomorrow? — Why, To-morrow I may be
22.four: Myself with Yesterday's Sev'n Thousand Years.

23.one: For some we loved, the loveliest and the best
23.two: That Time and Fate of all their Vintage prest,
23.three: Have drunk their Cup a Round or two before,
23.four: And one by one crept silently to Rest.

24.one: And we, that now make merry in the Room
24.two: They left, and Summer dresses in new Bloom,
24.three: Ourselves must we beneath the Couch of Earth
24.four: Descend, ourselves to make a Couch – for whom?

25.one: Ah, make the most of what we yet may spend,
25.two: Before we too into the Dust descend;
25.three: Dust into Dust, and under Dust to lie,
25.four: Sans Wine, sans Song, sans Singer, and — sans End!

26.one: Alike for those who for TO-DAY prepare,
26.two: And those that after a TO-MORROW stare,
26.three: A Muezzin from the Tower of Darkness cries
26.four: "Fools! Your reward is neither Here nor There!"

27.one: Why, all the Saints and Sages who discuss'd
27.two: Of the Two Worlds so learnedly, are thrust
27.three: Like foolish Prophets forth; their Words to Scorn
27.four: Are scatter'd, and their mouths are stopt with Dust.

28.one: Oh, come with old Khayyam, and leave the Wise
28.two: To talk; one thing is certain, that Life flies;
28.three: One thing is certain, and the Rest is Lies;
28.four: The Flower that once has blown for ever dies.

29.one: Myself when young did eagerly frequent
29.two: Doctor and Saint, and heard great Argument
29.three: About it and about: but evermore
29.four: Came out by the same Door where in I went.

30.one: With them the Seed of Wisdom did I sow,
30.two: And with my own hand labour’d it to grow:
30.three: And this was all the Harvest that I reap'd —
30.four: "I came like Water, and like Wind I go."

31.one: Into this Universe, and why not knowing,
31.two: Nor whence, like Water willy-nilly flowing:
31.three: And out of it, as Wind along the Waste,
31.four: I know not whither, willy-nilly blowing.

32.one: What, without asking, hither hurried, whence?
32.two: And without asking, whither hurried, hence?
32.three: Oh, many a Cup of this forbidden Wine
32.four: Must drown the memory of that insolence!

33.one: Up from Earth's Centre though the Seventh Gate
33.two: I rose, and on the Throne of Saturn sate,
33.three: And many a knot unravel'd by the Road;
33.four: But not the Master-knot of Human Fate.

34.one: There was a Door to which I found no Key:
34.two: There was a Veil past which I could not see:
34.three: Some little talk awhile of ME and THEE
34.four: There seem'd - and then no more of THEE and ME.

35.one: Then of the THEE IN ME who works behind
35.two: The Veil, I lifted up my hands to find
35.three: A Lamp amid the Darkness and I heard
35.four: As from Without – “THE ME WITHIN THEE BLIND!”

36.one: Then to the Lip of this poor earthen urn
36.two: I lean’d the Secret of my Life to learn
36.three: And Lip to Lip it murmur’d – “While you live,
36.four: “Drink! – for once dead you never shall return.

37.one: I think the Vessel, that with fugitive
37.three: And drink; and Ah! the cold Lip I kiss'd
37.four: How many Kisses might it take - and give!

38.one: For in the Market-place, one Dusk of Day,
38.two: I watch'd the Potter thumping his wet Clay:
38.three: And with its all obliterated Tongue

39.one: For has not such a Story from of Old
39.three: Of such a clod of saturated earth
39.four: Cast by the Maker into Human mould?

40.one: And not a drop that from our Cups we throw
40.two: For Earth to drink of, but may steal below
40.three: To quench the fire of Anguish in some Eye
40.four: There hidden — far beneath and long ago.

41.one: As then the Tulip for her morning sup
41.two: Of Heavenly Vintage lifts her chalice up
41.three: Do you, devoutly, do the like, till Heav’n
41.four: To Earth invert you like an empty cup.

42.one: Perplext no more with Human and Divine
42.two: Tomorrow’s tangle to the winds resign
42.three: And lose your fingers in the tresses of

43.one: And if the Wine you drink, the Lip you press
43.two: End in what All begins and ends in — Yes;
43.three: Think then you are TODAY what YESTERDAY
43.four: You were — TO-MORROW you shall not be less.

44.one: While the Rose blows along the River Brink,
44.two: With old Khayyam the Ruby Vintage drink
44.three: And when the Angel with his darker Draught
44.four: Draws up to Thee — take that and do not shrink.

45.one: Why, if the Soul can fling the Dust aside,
45.two: And naked on the Air of Heaven ride,
45.three: Wer’t not a Shame — wer’t not a Shame for him
45.four: In this clay carcase crippled to abide?

46.one: ‘Tis but a Tent where takes his one day’s rest
46.two: A Sultan to the realm of Death addrest;
46.three: The Sultan rises, and the dark Ferrash
46.four: Strikes, and prepares it for another Guest.

47.one: And fear not lest Existence closing your
47.two: Account, and mine, should know the like no more;
47.three: The Eternal Saki from that Bowl has pour’d
47.four: Millions of Bubbles like us, and will pour.

48.one: When you and I behind the Veil are past
48.two: O, but the long, long while the World shall last,
48.three: Which of our Coming and Departure heeds
48.four: As the Sea’s self should heed a pebble-cast.

49.one: A Moment’s Halt – a momentary taste
49.two: Of BEING from the Well amid the Waste –
49.three: And LO! – the phantom Caravan has reach’d
49.four: The NOTHING it set out from – Oh make haste!

50.one: Would you that Spangle of Existence spend
50.two: About THE SECRET — quick about it, Friend!
50.three: A Hair perhaps divides the False and True —
50.four: And upon what, prithee, may life depend?

51.one: A Hair perhaps divides the False and True
51.two: Yes, and a single Alif were the clue —
51.three: Could you but find it — to the Treasure-house,
51.four: And peradventure to The MASTER too;

52.one: Whose secret Presence, through Creation’s veins
52.three: Taking all shapes from Mah to Mahi; and
52.four: They change and perish all — but He remains.

53.one: A moment guess’d — then back behind the Fold
53.two: Immerst of Darkness round the Drama roll’d
53.three: Which, for the Pastime of Eternity,
53.four: He doth Himself contrive, enact, behold.

54.one: But if in vain, down on the stubborn floor
54.two: Of Earth, and up to Heav’n’s unopening Door
54.three: You gaze TODAY, while You are You — how then
54.four: TOMORROW when You shall be You no more?

55.one: Waste not your Hour, nor in the vain pursuit
55.two: Of This and That endeavour and dispute;
55.three: Better be merry with the fruitful grape
55.four: Than sadden after none, or bitter, fruit.

56.one: You know, my Friends, how long since in my House
56.two: For a new Marriage I did make Carouse:
56.three: Divorced old barren Reason from my Bed,
56.four: And took the Daughter of the Vine to Spouse.

57.one: For "IS" and "IS-NOT" though with Rule and Line,
57.three: Of all that one should care to fathom, I
57.four: Was never deep in anything but – Wine.

58.one: Ah, but my Computations, People say,
58.two: Reduced the Year to better reckoning?--Nay,

59.one: And lately, by the Tavern Door agape,
59.two: Came stealing through the Dusk an Angel Shape
59.three: Bearing a Vessel on his Shoulder; and
59.four: He bid me taste of it; and 'twas--the Grape!

60.one: The Grape that can with Logic absolute
60.three: The subtle Alchemist that [can] in a Trice
60.four: Life's leaden Metal into Gold transmute:

61.one: But leave the Wise to wrangle, and with me
61.two: The Quarrel of the Universe let be:
61.three: And, in some corner of the Hubbub coucht,
61.four: Make Game of that which makes as much of Thee.

62.one: Why, be this Juice the growth of God, who dare
62.two: Blaspheme the twisted tendril as a Snare?
62.three: A Blessing, we should use it, should we not?
62.four: And if a Curse — why, then. Who set it there?

63.one: I must abjure the Balm of Life, I must,
63.two: Scared by some After-reckoning ta'en on trust,
63.three: Or lured with Hope of some Diviner Drink,
63.four: To fill the Cup — when crumbled into Dust!

64.one: Strange, is it not? that of the myriads who
64.two: Before us pass'd the door of Darkness through,
64.three: Not one returns to tell us of the Road,
64.four: Which to discover we must travel too.

65.one: The Revelations of Devout and Learn'd
65.two: Who rose before us, and as Prophets burn'd,
65.three: Are all but Stories, which, awoke from Sleep
65.four: They told their fellows, and to Sleep return'd.

66.one: I sent my Soul through the Invisible,
66.two: Some letter of that After-life to spell:
66.three: And by and by my Soul return'd to me,
66.four: And answer'd "I Myself am Heav'n and Hell”:

67.one: Heav'n but the Vision of fulfill'd Desire,
67.two: And Hell the Shadow of a Soul on fire,
67.three: Cast on the Darkness into which Ourselves,
67.four: So late emerg'd from, shall so soon expire.

68.one: For in and out, above, about, below,
68.three: Play'd in a Box whose Candle is the Sun,
68.four: Round which we Phantom Figures come and go.

69.one: 'Tis all a Chequer-board of Nights and Days
69.two: Where Destiny with Men for Pieces plays:
69.three: Hither and thither moves, and mates, and slays,
69.four: And one by one back in the Closet lays.

70.one: The Moving Finger writes; and, having writ,
70.two: Moves on: nor all thy Piety nor Wit
70.three: Shall lure it back to cancel half a Line,
70.four: Nor all thy Tears wash out a Word of it.

71.one: And that inverted Bowl they call the Sky,
71.two: Whereunder crawling coop'd we live and die,
71.three: Lift not your hands to It for help — for It
71.four: As impotently moves as you or I.

72.one: YESTERDAY This Day's Madness did prepare;
72.three: Drink! for you know not whence you came, nor why:
72.four: Drink! for you know not why you go, nor where.

73.one: The Vine had struck a fibre: which about
73.two: If clings my Being — let the Sufi flout;
73.three: Of my Base metal may be filed a Key,
73.four: That shall unlock the Door he howls without.

74.one: And this I know: whether the one True Light
74.two: Kindle to Love, or Wrath-consume me quite,
74.three: One Flash of It within the Tavern caught
74.four: Better than in the Temple lost outright.

75.one: What! Out of senseless Nothing to provoke
75.two: A conscious Something to resent the yoke

76.one: What! from his helpless Creature be repaid
76.two: Pure Gold for what he lent us dross-allay'd;
76.three: Sue for a Debt we never did contract,
76.four: And cannot answer? — Oh the sorry trade!

77.one: Oh Thou, who didst with pitfall and with gin
77.two: Beset the Road I was to wander in,
77.three: Thou wilt not with Predestin'd Evil round
77.four: Enmesh me and impute my Fall to Sin!

78.one: Oh Thou, who Man of baser Earth didst make,
78.two: And ev'n with Eden didst devise the Snake:
78.three: For all the Sin wherewith the Face of Man
78.four: Is blacken'd — Man's Forgiveness give — and take!

79.one: Listen again, One Evening at the Close
79.two: Of Ramazán, ere the better Moon arose,
79.three: In that old Potter's Shop I stood alone
79.four: With the clay Population round in Rows.

80.one: And once again there gather’d a scarce heard
80.two: Whisper among them; as it were, the stirr’d
80.three: Ashes of some all but extinguisht Tongue
80.four: Which mine ear kindled into living Word.

81.one: Said one among them — “Surely not in vain,
81.two: “My Substance from the common Earth was ta’en,
81.three: “ That He who subtly wrought me into Shape
81.four: “Should stamp me back to shapeless Earth again.”

82.one: Another said — “Why, ne’er a peevish Boy,
82.two: “Would break the Bowl from which he drank in Joy;
82.three: “And He that with his hand the Vessel made
82.four: “Will surely not in after Wrath destroy.”

83.two: Some Vessel of more ungainly Make:
83.three: “They sneer at me for leaning all awry;
83.four: “What! Did the Hand then of the Potter shake?”

84.one: Whereat some one of the loquacious Lot —
84.two: I think a Sufi pipkin — waxing hot —
84.three: “All this of Pot and Potter — Tell me then,
84.four: “Who is the Potter, pray, and who the Pot?”

85.one: “Why”, said another, “Some there are who tell
85.two: “Of one who threatens he will toss to Hell
85.three: “The luckless Pots he marr’d in making — Pish!
85.four: “He’s a Good Fellow, and ‘twill all be well.”

86.one: Then said another with a long drawn Sigh,
86.two: “My Clay with long oblivion is gone dry:
86.three: “But fill me with the old familiar Juice,
86.four: “Methinks I might recover by and by.”

87.one: Ah, with the Grape my fading Life provide,
87.two: And wash my Body whence the Life has died,
87.three: And in a Windingsheet of Vine-leaf wrapt,
87.four: So bury me by some sweet Garden-side

88.one: That ev’n my buried Ashes such a Snare
88.two: Of Perfume shall fling up into the Air,
88.three: As not a True Believer passing by

89.one: Indeed the Idols I have loved so long
89.two: Have done my Credit in Men’s Eye much wrong,
89.three: Have drown’d my Honour in a shallow Cup
89.four: And sold my Reputation for a Song.

90.two: I swore – but was I sober when I swore?
90.three: And then, and then came Spring, and Rose-in-hand

91.one: And much as Wine has play’d the Infidel,
91.two: And robb’d me of my Robe of Honour – well,
91.three: I often wonder what the Vintners buy
91.four: One half so precious as the Goods they sell.

92.one: Alas, that Spring should vanish with the Rose!
92.two: That Youth’s sweet-scented Manuscript should close!
92.three: The Nightingale that in the Branches sang,
92.four: Ah, whence, and whither flown again who knows!

93.one: Would that some winged Angel ere too late
93.two: Arrest the yet unfolded Roll of Fate,
93.three: And make the stern Recorder otherwise

94.one: Ah Love! could thou and I with Fate conspire
94.two: To grasp the sorry Scheme of Things entire,
94.three: Would not we shatter it to bits – and then
94.four: Re-mould it nearer to the Heart’s Desire!

95.one: Ah, Moon of my Delight who know’st no wane,
95.two: The Moon of Heav’n is rising once again:
95.three: How oft hereafter rising shall it look
95.four: Through this same Garden after me – in vain!

96.one: And when Thyself with shining Foot shall pass
96.two: Among the Guests Star-scatter’d on the Grass,
96.three: And in thy joyous Errand reach the Spot
96.four: Where I made one — turn down an empty Glass
